review:
I have been playing the custom made maps and the campaign more than the laggy bugged out multiplayer. I live in Alaska and my lat is 200 and up. No localized content not even one in Seattle or Portland to lower it under 200. So when I play online I have to aim in some funky spot other than where the player is to be able to get a kill. 

Pros
Graphics are impressive in ultra settings
Very low FPS drop
Campaign has me fully hooked so far
Controller support is solid

Cons
Can't play co-op till after act 1 is finished basically so that sucks
being connected with u-play sucks
Not being able to skip any cut scenes naturally sucks specially for the intro (atleast the multiplayer is a 1 time deal)
No real stealth mode for hunting, once you get within 100 feet they split and a badger, boar, wolf, pig, monkey should only take 1 shot from an AK-47. 
Some minor glitches - lags out in pagan min compound after going down stairs, glitches when you jump in the truck after escaping the compound (i was stuck sitting on the head rest of the seat, took 2 mins to get the truck to move after running to it, the gun wouldn't cycle till we were about to be slammed off the cliff.
it was a 3 cycle of that quest to get it to run right and smoothly.

In all I think the major fuck up is the multiplayer and the co-op other than that it is fun and entertaining. But I would like some free run similar to maybe what mordor is like, run where ever take over the tower open the quests. Why not, what if we want to explore the whole map before we run the missions, maybe we would like to unlock everything so we can choose what to do other than end the game of course. Or maybe like me hunt and build up my storage capacity without being reset back to the main mission area.

review:
A very good game, and improvement on the franchise. However, be warned! the game is an open-outlet for whiney bitch-boys (boi's?) and fan fucks who had their dreams and life dashed and scattered tot he wind, when they found that Far cry 4, was NOT infact the end-all-be-all of gaming revolultion. 

Therefore, they now needlessly troll the reviews, claim the game is bad (obvious trolls needs obvious butt-fuck), and that the game wont run(mine has worked flawlessly), because their shitty machines are too far out of date, that minecraft freezes up when they try and play it.

In a nutshell, solid gaming experience, fun and exciting game, a little repetitive, but all-in-all a solid 9/10. and a solid 10/10 on the butt-hurt troll scale.

===[ Comments ]=== 

Far Cry 4 reuses a lot of assets from Far Cry 3, which makes it feel like Far Cry 3.5. The game puts you in Kyrat which is a nice change from islands. The story is a bit lacking, you're Ajay Ghale who went to Kyrat to scatter your mothers ashes and you get involved in a civil war between the Royal Army and the Golden Path. Your character has next to no emotion and doesn't question the decisions that the Golden Path makes. As you progress through the storyline, you unlock more weapons to use. The main villan Pagan Min occasionally calls you and talks to you for a bit, he doesn't show any actual anger or distaste towards you, he treats you like his son.

review:
Super dissapointed.

I LOVED Far Cry 3 and Blood Dragon. LOVED em!

I also have no problem with the "next game" being similar to the last game. (Just don't make it worse and include plenty of new story/experience).


But Far Cry 4 is wonky and unhappy for me.  Story missions seem stuck in weirdly between the grinding. Often I'll be on a mission and be sidetracked by an "event" that interrupts the mission itself. I actually had trouble figuring out what to do next on several occasions...but not in a good way. 

I mean...that'd be awesome if it was a world full of possiblities and I could do anything! But it's a world full of grinding and I couldn't figure out how to advance the game (even so I could grind efficiently with waypoints and belltowers in the North).



When the game actually gets in the way of the game itself, something has gone wrong.  The "improvements" they made over Far Cry 3 were mistakes that break immersion and pull you out of the story and into the "open world" aka "grind".


I'd still give it a 6/10 and plan to finish it..but I'm hella dissapointed. (I'd have rated FC3 9/10 and hoped to rate this somewhere between 8/10 and 10/10).

Maybe FC5 will be better...but I won't be preordering it.

review:
Fun game, but the fact the game decides to save once every 5 hours and completely ignores my manual save makes it deserve a thumbs down.

EDIT: The game was fixed not long after my review. Farcry 4 is a lot like Farcry 3, in fact it's really just a reskin with a new story line, but that doesn't mean it's not fun as hell. Definitely recommended.

review:
DON'T BE A BABY, FIND SOMEONE WITH THIS GAME AND TRY IT OR BUY IT OUTRIGHT. WAIT FOR A SALE IF YOU HAVE TO OR WHATEVER.

I was super shocked to find out this game was scored by Cliff Martinez of Drive and Only god forgives soundtracks!

A near perfect game for me. I think people dismissing this on the basis of it being Ubisoft alone are really missing out; If you are truly voting for your wallet, buy the good games, don't just ignore them all. If they can't win your dollar, they will never try to.

For those dismissing it on buginess, for the few remaining bugs, there are many fixes. Ubisoft was good about getting patches out immediately. For those dismissing it on the basis of being Far Cry 3.5, I feel this game has far more to offer both story and gameplay wise than 3 ever did. Far cry 3 feels like a demo by comparison.

I was satisfied with the way the story played out, and those who have an emotional, reactionary personality will find themselves stuck with a very bad ending. Pay attention, be rational, think, and you will get the best outcome this game has to offer.

I can't spoil the gameplay. It's goofy, over the top, action oriented, and beautiful. Performance has been fine. The characters are solid; even the ones I disliked I never wanted to be out of the game. I'm dissapointed you can't coop in the campaign missions, whatever though, the freeroam is great. If you miss the 4-player specialized coop campaign from Far cry 3. ehh, not my thing, I felt it was very derivative of other "coop" shooters. There's enough borderlands, not nearly enough open-range-fps-skyrim-with-guns-coop games out there.

Multiplayer seems neat, can't speak for it much but, takedowns and everyone gets a wingsuit? yes please.

Ubisoft, YOU DONE GOOD. More of these, less Assassin's creed, please.

review: I would give this game a 9/10.  I love the environment and the same feel of combat from Far Cry 3, while mixing in new mechanics, like picking up and hiding bodies, that make the game feel a little different then Far Cry 3.  There is also a ton of new content to do after you finish the main storyline and plenty of collectibles and new places to explore.  Not to mention that the co-op is extremely fun.

review: Even though the company ubisoft dissapoints with games like Watch dogs and Ac: Unity, this is not one of their games where it is dissapointing. review:
[h1]More of the same[/h1]
If you've been sitting at the Far Cry dinner table and wished you could have seconds of Far Cry 3, you're in luck.

If you were looking for something innovative and totally new that didn't cut corners by using previous assets, this is not the game for you.

That being said, I really liked Far Cry 3 and didn't mind paying $60 for a second run-through with a fresh purpose and storyline.  I just wish they would have changed the skinning animations or the radio tower mechanics.  Far Cry 4 is basically suped-up Far Cry 3, but this time you get a bunch of different grenade launchers and a one-man helicopter called a "Buzzer", which is invaluable.

The Arena in Far Cry 4 is probably my favorite part - pulse-pounding survival game that is chaotic, and crazy kills and chain combos are rewarded with health, ammo, and the roar of the crowd.  Also boobs at the entrance.

review:
This game is awesome. Improved on what Far Cry 3 had already brought to the table (aside from story, which is not horrible but could have had a tad bit more time sunk into its deveolopment). In all honesty it is very much like Far Cry 3, however as I mentioned above they improved upon many things that Far Cry 3 was lacking. 

If you enjoyed Far Cry 3 and dumped tons of time into it, you wont be dissapointed with Far Cry 4. Oh and one more thing, if you can play coop, play coop as it is super fun with a friend :)

review:
It has a bit more interesting world then Far Cry 3's, but honestly not that much, 
all there is is random events, which in total exist of like 3 or 4, random animals can be where they shouldn't, and there's more outposts, that's all they did. See those fancy giant snowy mountains that you want to explore, that they kept showing off in trailers? All backgrounds, the only time you ever explore them is a 5 minute mission that forces you there, you can't travel there or go back ever agqain afterwards.
This game is a complete rip off if you already played Far Cry 3, you'd basically be getting the same exact expierence just about with a few "neat" toys. You're basically spending 60$ for a texture pack amd a helicopter. This game is also much more stable pirated even though it doesn't have a FoV option, it runs better then the payed version. If you played Far Cry 3 already there's no point getting this game. It's basically a DLC and I've heavily regretted paying 60$ on this game. This game honestly has a low quality build and is really piss poor considering what we should be able to do in this gen of gaming, this is honestly more of a 2010 game. Just because it has fancy visuals and animation doesn't make it good in the least, the game honestly in the end is more of a 30$ game. Though I am having fun with it, that doesn't mean I'm gonna look at it from a fair logical view.

5/10, it's not terrible. Though wasted my only 60$ my family could get on on Xmas. (we celebrated early because things get busy, we celebrate when we have a chance)
I much rather would of been much happier using all my 60$ on all these steam sales. Though I should of waited.

review:
Summary of what I will go into detail about:
This is Far Cry 3 but improved it practically everyway possible.  Everything that made it good is back and better if it could be better.  Upgrade even more weapons, more paintable skins.  The Side Missions are plentiful and there is so much to see off the beaten path.  You will ultimately dictate how much fun you have in the game.


More Details:

Weapons:  The game has about the same setup for weapons.  You unlock 3 more slots but now your first unlockable weapon slot is a sidearm slot for pistols and smaller guns like a single shot grenade launcher.  There are a lot of weapons.  I don't have a precise # but I know it's like 30 or so and even more if you count the signature weapons. 

Animals/People: There are more animals in the wild and they are even more deadly than they were before.  Animals are a force to be afraid of early on but become more of a fun play thing to toy with once you unlock everything.  The enemies are plentiful as well and random fights happen more often.  They are also a bit more intelligent and aren't as simple as before to kill.  Of course when you unlock the North side of the map they get even harder and are a bit more of a challenge.  My suggestion is aim for the head and if your aim is true they will not stand a chance.

Story: 
It was rather interesting and entertaining.  It kept you wanting to learn more but this also conflicts with me wanting to unlock as much as I can and just play around.  Overall the basic idea of the game is pretty solid and works well.  Although I still have to wonder how another random man from the states is so deadly.

Side Missions:
This is a big one.  There are tons of types of side missions you can do.  There are a few race types which are fairly easy to get gold on without having to be really good at driving.  The other missions are either save hostages and you can't be spotted otherwise they execute them or assassination missions where you have to kill a commander and loot him and escape without being spotted.  You can also get a bonus for hiding his body before you leave.  Another type has you kill 2 commanders with a certain weapon type which allows you to use your own weapon of that type of you want which is a nice change of pace.  The hunting missions works the same way as well which I really liked.  There are a few more that I am not thinking of but they are all fairly entertaining.

Unlockables/Skills:
This game has a lot of guns and things that can be earned and unlocked.  You get XP as well as you kill enemies and you get more based on how they die.  Head shots earn more xp and Heavy Enemies(hard to kill especially early on) give quite a bit more.  You can also do karma events which are random events like save a hostage who is being taken out in the wilderness by 1 or 2 guys.  Pretty easy to do.  Help the rebels kill the Royal Army which is simple.  There are a few that are simple like this that give you a chance to earn extra karma xp outside of doing missions.  These levels you get here unlock more Guns for Hire Tokens and you can upgrade them which allows you to call in rebels to help you fight.  The guns you unlock by either picking them up or purchasing them.  Some guns you start with being able to be purchased while other unlock after a certain point into the main story.  By getting to the top of the Bell Towers  you can unlock some weapons without purchasing.  Signature weapons are unique though in that they are normal weapons but with specific attachments on them which cannot be changed but they are better than they would normally be.  Most of the regular weapons can be upgraded with scope/sight attachments, silencer or larger magazines.  They all also have different paints you can apply as well.

Upgrades and other things I missed:
You can upgrade your pouches and wallet by skinning animals and crafting them when you get a certain amount.  If you get a clean kill by using a bow and arrow or a auto-cross which uses bolts, you can get 2 hides per animal instead of just 1.  You have to be careful though since some weapons might damage the hides.  I suggest not using a Elephant gun to kill any small game if you want hides.  There are Molotovs, Grenades, Throwing Knifes and Bait which will attract wild beasts to the area to attach your enemies.

Co-Op/Multiplayer/Editor:
You are limited in distance from your partner and you can't do the main story with them as well.  Other than that though it is pretty awesome.  I have yet to try Multiplayer vs or anything so I can't really say how that is.  I also have not used or tried to use the Editor.


I am probably forgetting something so if you have a question please leave a comment and I'll try to answer it for you.

review: If i could get this to run more than 15 minuts at a time without crashing it would be just as good as far cry 3. i have a powerfull system i5 processor, 16g ram, SSD for game disc, and a GEForce 970 so i should be able to run this without problems. But sadly i have only been able to play 13 hours with difficulty and now its has become unplayable, it crashes within 5 min, i have tryed this more than 20 times and i have given up. Sadly course this is a kickass game if it would just run probably :( i hope for a fix soon! Save your money untill more bug fixes/optimization is out

review:
Con Ranty Bit (Please Read this may be important to you!)

Far Cry 4 isn't so amazing as what the critics say. It is a very finished game and that's the problem. If this game was in early access I might be able to forgive it but it's not, so there is no excuse for a lack of content. There are a total of about 15 Guns in the game, not counting the Flamethrowers, 2 Rocketlaunchers, and the bow. You may think this is an okay amount and I'm being too hard but I don't think I'm being hard enough. The first two hand guns can be immediatly discounted as they do little to no damage against the enemy and the MP34 is a terrible weapon. You will almost no matter what end up using the AK-47, Scorpin, and RPG/Bow seeing as these are the most cheap and available weapons and do the most damage. Now people who play the game will say "Oh what about the signatures", well let me tell you about the signatures THEY ARE COMPLETE BULL! The game restricts you from putting attachments on the early guns so that you have to save up for the signatures to get say the first pistol with a silencer. It is a crappy way to stretch the content. Vehicles are extremely lame and traffic is non-existant. You'll see the odd enemy encounter, sure. But Civilians are extremely rare (I've almost completed the game and only seen two outside of the base and missions) and your allies are rarely there.  

Pro Bit:

"Intresting Story"
"Odd Missions"
"Fucking Helicopters"
Co-Op Campaign (Not multiplayer that's shit too)

I'm too lazy so take my word when I say 6/10 if you have patience and a good comp go for it. But I'd wait til it's on sale/

review:
I have only played 4 hours (so far), and in that time I find that it's not very immersive because they have to run those dang black bars on the screen (on 16:10 monitors). It pisses me off, because I paied 60 bucks for an unfinished game. The story is great, as otherwise I would recommend, but don't spend 60 bucks on a half finished game that was rushed to PC. Vote with your money...

Developer Tips:
   -Optimize the game. It runs good, but can have some ocassional slowdown on 18GB of RAM with 4 GB of GDDR3
   -Keep the game glitches that don't break the game. They're really funny as hell, but 720p is nothing to laugh about...
   -Fix the 16:10 issue. Why would we have to be forced into a aspect that degrades the quality of the game, or have to                  buy a whole new monitor?

review: In my opinion i have loved Far Cry 3 a lot . When i got it , i started to go crazy and played it every day . But then when i got Far Cry 4 i went mad . When it finished pre-loading and unpacking i started the game and , Poof... black screen and sometimes it says 'not responding '. I was highly disappointed when this occured over 50 times and still isn't fixed . When the patches came out for grey and black screen issues i tried again... but it still didn't work . So i'd suggest if you're those people who are thinking of buying it , than i'd say follow Far Cry 4 and wait for other reviews for a positive one.

review:
This is Far Cry 3 on steroids. It's seriously more fun, there's a ton more to do, much more variety in missions and the characters - at least some of them - have a bit of personality. So many little annoyances from 3 were fixed, and 3 in itself was already a great game. One thing specially worth noting are the Himalayas missions, which allow for a very welcome change in scenery from time to time. The nature is unpredictable, the missions allow for a lot of personal flexibility and ... okay, let's face it: Violence is fun and in this scale and detail, it's very fun, It also looks good, at least if you have some decent GPU power. 

Downsides would include some UI/control features that cause the game to do just about the opposite of what you wanted. Some small bugs still remain after the first big patch, but nothing major. Oh, and those gliding scenes here and there are just stupid, far more random luck than skill is needed. One of the Shangri La quests had a gliding/flying part that I had to retry a good 50+ times.

Good stuff. Seriously.

review:
Fun game but not as good as I hoped.  I enjoyed Far Cry 3 quite a bit more.

The only thing I really alot that they added to this game that wasn't in 3 was the gyrocopter.  I have to admit I used it to unlock a lot of towers without having to climb to the top.  Maybe not what they intended but I found it very convenient towards my goal of unlocking all towers/outposts to get the best weapons.

I feel they added a lot more annoyances this time around that made the gameplay more annoying.

Eagles - They swoop in without warning and fly away out of sight.  Not fun at all!
Radio announcer - Guy sounds like a douchebag american and you can't turn just him off.  You can turn off the raidio station and the announcer but not just the announcer, which makes changing the radio station pointless.
Mortors - It's a lot harder to take out an outpost at long range because you get one shot from the mortors unless you have line of sight to kill everyone who tries to man the mortor.
Sneak/limited weapon missions - They have more missions that require you to sneak around and not be seen and/or only have a crappy weapon like a knife limiting your choice on how to play.

I felt it also took to long to unlock the quest "A Key to the North" which unlocks all your health bar skills, all outposts and towers.  Some signiture weapons are significantly better than other weapons and you can't get these until you unlock that mission.  I would have liked more options to be able to use those weapons sooner.

I liked the story and theme of FarCry 3.  Vaas was the best bad guy ever and I could hang out inthe beautiful tropical islands all day.

So yeah, this game is fun but not as good as my all time favorite game, Far Cry 3.

review:
I like it. A lot of people are upset because it's so much like FC3, and that's a perfectly valid thing to get upset about. I find much more content in this game though. The grappling hook and MANY cliffs you'll face give the huge map verticality. There are quite a few guns to choose from too. The interface is much more PC friendly than FC3, but still not perfect. Beds are back from FC2 as well. This is definitely a Far Cry. I can't speak of the story, as I've yet to play all that much of it, but it seems interesting.

All in all, buy this game. 9/10.

review: I'm a little iffy about giving this too much praise as far as gameplay goes. On that topic, I have to say this. It's a spruced up version of the last title. Lots of recycled animations, and the overall feel of it just screams its predecessor. Even includes much of the exploits of it. Is that bad? I suppose you could call it a little disappointing... But why fix what isn't broken? FarCry3 was a ton of fun. As far as the story goes? It feels a tad rushed at parts, and shallow at others. They fail to make you get emotionally attached to the characters who are supposed to be your allies... But once I finished I knew why. The twist at the end is tingling.

It feels a tad rushed at parts, and shallow at others. They fail to make you get emotionally attached to the characters who are supposed to be your allies... But once I finished I knew why. The twist at the end is tingling.", "timestamp_created": 1417303135, "timestamp_updated": 1417303162, "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "weighted_vote_score": 0.5, "comment_count": 0, "steam_purchase": true, "received_for_free": false, "written_during_early_access": false, "primarily_steam_deck": false}

review: Far Cry 4 is Far Cry 3 on steroids: more exploration, more missions, more animals, more vehicles, and more signature weapons. In addition to the hours and hours that you will spend by yourself in single player, Far Cry 4 comes with PVP multiplayer and Co-op modes that are both well thought out and ridiculously fun. Simply put, I paid full price for this game and, for this first time in a long time, I do not regret it in the slightest.

review:
I would call this game more like Far Cry 3.5, there are a couple new features to the game but it largely uses the same game mechanics as the last one. The rocky terrain is a fresh change though and the modes of how you traverse the landscape definately work with the game. The story seemed a bit stale except for the occasional bump or two however the voice acting is top notch. I reccomend you do all of the side missions involving characters, they are why I played that game so long.

8.5/10

review:
Although its a game that loudly proclaims its aim to be an open world, non-linear and co-op friendly experience it fails to deliver on so many levels. The co-op is limited to side quests and side activities - asbolutely no co-operative experience to progress the main campaign which is often where you need the extra help.

Annoying, involuntary and lengthy animations can be very disruptive and can often be the cause of a stupidly frustrating death. For example, when climbing a ladder you are stuck looking forward the entire time, including for a good 2-3 seconds as you reach the top of the ladder. Now just imagine you are climbing a ladder to infiltrate an enemy outpost.. 2-3 seconds is a long time where you are clearly visible to the enemy and you cannot react to whatever happens. That is just one of the stupid annoying animations. There are many throughout the game that might look okay in trailers or may even look okay the first time you see them.. but after that they just get in the way. For an open world game you would think that liberty and freedom is a high priority for the developers - Farcry 4 doesn't seem to have this focus at all.

Unskippable cinematics. *Face slam*. Yet again, unskippable cinematics with 100% cheesy/sleasy cinematics that I have no reason to watch. I have a distinct distaste every time I have to watch another one of the cinematics. For a modern game, it is absurd and arrogant that they don't have the ability to skip cinematics, especially when they are so incredibly unnecessary to the story.

Someone asked me if this was like Farcry 3 with elephants... well no!

It is a sequel and so that means some will be carried over but I have to say this game is superior to FC3 is some ways.

The environment, I feel, is just cooler.  Elephants.  Some weapons are different.

There are some people complaining that it is cut and paste but what about Assassins creed?  I love the formula of FC3 and I am glad they stuck to it.  The time difference between the 2 games isn't that much but there is that much there that FC3 players would love to play it.  And so quickly after FC3!  

Buy it.  It's a great game.  The shangri la sequences are epic.

Love it.  More detailed than fc3, had to turn my system options down a bit.

Still great.

review:
Very fun to play and beautiful to look at. It doesn't boast anything "ground breaking" like Destiny or Advance Warfare, it has built upon Farcry 3 and has more content and a different location. I really enjoyed Farcry 3 and this is a polished version of that, meaning all the improvements they've made I've greatly enjoyed. All the new features are great and easy to get adjusted to. I still wish they would allow you to skip cutscenes, but then again it forces me to get into the story. 

Some new features I really enjoyed:
-Being able to disable brakes outside the vehicle; place on a hill and watch em go.
-Grappling hook makes scaling mountain sides much faster so you can jump off em. The grappling system works surprisingly well, being able to swing around and ungrapple. It is very easy to learn and adapt to, but there are only certain grapple points which can be frustrating to find, especially if one entire mountain side doesn't have one.
-Throwing knives are awesome and satisfying
-The physics are the same from FC3, i.e., bullets shoot straight and gravity's hold on arrows is ever so slight
-There are a lot of cool little caves to explore that are fairly detailed and different, I spent a bit of time crashing into mountain sides trying to get near a cave.
-Vehicles have an auto-drive which is AMAZING. It allows you to actually shoot back at other vehicles and people rather than raining bullets into the air.
-The mini helicopter is awesome and gets you where you need to go and over those pesky mountains.
-Outposts are replayable. This is a great feature and gives you something to do after you beat the game. I've done so many varieties of outpost clearing because of this, throwing knives only, melee only, shotgun only, desert eagle only, grenades only, etc
-The location is amazing just to look at. Similar to Skyrim for it's vast appearance when you reach the top of a huge mountain or are just cruising with the auto-drive and able to see some great sights.
-Side missions are great and add a bit of variety and random diversions. 
-Map editor is pretty cool and people come up with some great maps. It isn't the hardest to use, but requires creativity and patience. Worth checking out.

Those are just a few of the new features I enjoyed, there are plenty more. All in all this game still brought a crazy amount of randomness and hilarity. My first hour playing I accidentally machete'd a civilian in the face who was getting attacked by an eagle; the eagle few away right as I was swinging. I felt terrible cause their husband watched me brutally kill them by accident. I saw three of my rebel buddies I just saved in a firefight get mowed down by a civilian speeding in a van. 

I highly recommend this game if you want something that is just fun to play, this won't revolutionize the way you see gaming, but it will keep you entertained.

review:
Pretty much the same game as Far Cry 3, with all the flaws, but without the bits that made that game one of my favourites. The story tastes like cardboard, with a blank-slate protagonist with absolutely no character (as opposed to Brodie, from FC3, who had a wonderful character arc balancing simultaneously blossoming strength and psychopathy), and tone that jumps madly about between serious and silly (rather than managing to combine the two, as FC3 did). 
Hunting has been UTTERLY RUINED. You go to the spawn area for the animal, throw some bait, and literally 2 seconds later, the animal shows up to eat it, and you shoot it from the perfect safety of your vehicle mounted machine gun. No fun left in it at all.
Events and animal attacks are constant to the point of being incredibly tiresome. You can't travel even a short distance without a karma event popping up - save this guy, kill that guy - and there's not that many, so the same ones keep on coming up. It's often quite hard to stealth attack a base because random animal encounters are so frequent that you'll be trying to silently snipe someone and be attacked by yet another bloody honey badger or pack of dogs. And eagles? Don't even get me started.
Maybe if you've got an extremely bad case of ADHD and can't stand a single moment without something attacking you or needing to be attacked, you might find this an improvement on FC3.

review: Overall I love Far Cry 4, but I've reached a point in the game that quite a few other people (check both Ubisoft and Steam forums) have also experienced where the game won't continue into Act 3.    Act 2 ends, screen goes black (won't say why) and then it just sits there and nothing happens.   If you dare to force close the game when you come back you won't be able to continue any more campaign missions,  no minimap, weapon slots won't save,  and no health bar.   Game is unplayable beyond this point.  I've spent some 30+ hours up to this point in the game and now I can't progress.    Sorry - can't recommend this to anyone.

Sorry - can't recommend this to anyone.", "timestamp_created": 1417233827, "timestamp_updated": 1417233827, "voted_up": false, "votes_up": 2, "votes_funny": 0, "weighted_vote_score": 0.5, "comment_count": 0, "steam_purchase": true, "received_for_free": false, "written_during_early_access": false, "primarily_steam_deck": false}

review:
Far Cry 4 is Amazing even though there are some Cons but the Pros outwiegh the Cons. And i'm sure there are some Pros and Cons i'm missing. 

Pros:
*More Weapons. 
*Helicopters are used in Reinforcements for Outposts and Forts when alarms are triggered.
*Reinforcements are Doubled or Trippled when Alarms are triggered in Outposts and Forts.
*Fortresses. 
*Gyrocopter.
*More Animals and Elephants that can be driven.
*Bait to distract or kill enemies.
*Throwing knives and Sticky explosives.
*Guns for Hire and Coop. 
*Controlled Outposts can be retook by Enemies.  

Cons: 
*Weapon Attachments for AK-47, SVD, M1911, STG-90 and many other weapons that don't support attachments in the game but actually do in reality. 
*Control Keybinds. Hopefully this will be Patched soon.
*Helicopters. Can't pilot the Sikorsky UH-60 Helicopter.

review:
PROS: Hmm, what should I do next? Oh, I know: excuse me while I ride an elephant and charge through a fortress sporting a flamethrower. Or perhaps I should go hunting from my mini helicopter for rhinos using a grenade launcher. The possibilities are endless. 11/10 would play again.

CONS: Oh what's that? You wanted exciting boss fights? Well too bad, this game does not deliver in this category. Shoot someone in the head and be done with it.

~Mr Sniffels~

Far cry 4, is a major improvement from far cry 3. While far cry 3 is still a fantastic game it was missing some immersion aspects that far cry 4 has hit the head of the nail on. let's start with graphics.

Far cry 4's graphics are almost movie-like. With fantastic animations, great foliage and shadowing, the game looks simply brilliant. It has a nice Game look to it without it looking fake, unreal and Non-immersiable. while i have only played a miniscule amount of the game, i can already tell that it will take off to become on my top games. 

Gameplay, Far cry 4 started out fantastic. the characters are great, connectable, and you can really imagine the reality of them. Even the main antagonist is fantastic, honestely i would totally be on his side of things, and that would be a great twist. The talking amongst various NPC to NPC's is also not terrible. You don't necessarily hear, "I used to be an adventurer like you, until i took an arrow to the knee" a thousand times until it becomes hardy-har funny. It uses a fantastic amount of realism and is overall a very immerseful experience.

Hunting, the hunting in Far cry 4 is fantabulous. It's honestly. I can't get enough of it. It is too easy to be walking along see a deer and end up on the other end of the map wingsuiting down from a bridge following a river all the way down to a small lake that i can fish at, well more like unload on the water until stuff floats up. But, the point is that it's great.

Co-op.  The Co-op in far cry 4 is exactly what i hoped it would have been in far cry 3 only better. It has a fantastic selection of things to do and if you run out of things to do because you and a friend are simply too badass, then reset the outposts.! It's amazing how that can restore the fun back into the game and keep you coming back for more action packed hunting, killing, looting, driving, and exploration. 

Rate 9.5/10 - fantastic game. very well done. Bravo sir.

review:
a lot of people compare it (and rightfuly so) to far cry 3, but i choose to compare it to far cry 2. just like far cry 2, this game is riddled with bugs, glitches, it will crash every so often and everything and everyone wants, and will go out of their way, to kill you. just like in far cry 2 you use beds to advance time by sleeping. and just like in far cry 2, your seemingly obvious choice makes people's lives worse. if far cry 3 was far cry 2 in a new dress, then this is fac cry 2 with new shoes as well. tap dancing shoes to be precise, as almost every few minutes you'll be pulled into an adventure of your own making. if you can find a friend that bought this game as well (or bought the god awful crime of a game assassin's creed unity and was reimbursed by free far cry 4), you can get so much fun out of this game, as the overall chaos and stupidity can get doubled.

storywise however, this is where this game really wants to shine, yet drowns in typical far cry storytelling. you will never fully understand who the characters are, as they are just thrown at you and then they kick you out to do repetitive killing ,honestly, it took me almost six main missions to start piecing together the characters and their motivations. you want to know more about kyrati customs and traditions to better understand the world? run around that very world for hours, reading scraps of paper scattered about to realize why the little girl you only see three times is so important. you will never care for the kyrati people ,as there simply aren't any, it's like everyone was eaten by omnipresent wolves and eagles or shot by the army. all you'll ever care about is getting more of pagan min (brillianty voice by troy baker), the most sympathetic, charming, smart and well written character of the cast, partly because every time he shows up you remember that this game has a story, not a bad one at that, hidden somewhere between recycled bits and bytes of this beatiful and vast world (if ubisoft can make something besides trailers, it's open world maps). 

in short, while i do recommend it, especially in coop, i strongly criticize the price tag. this game should not cost so much, as it isn't worth it and definetly cost far cry 2 budget, or less, to make

"Like Skyrim with badgers."

10/10

-Machinima

Great game to play alone or with friends! I have spent several hours in game conquering bases and unlocking the secrets of the north. While the story isn't amazing, the co-op gameplay makes up for that and the game's graphics are amazing on PCs that can handle high or better :)

review:
Did you enjoy Far Cry 3? If yes you'll enjoy this game. More of the same in a different setting with a few new features. 

Stand out weakness - Points on the map lack deep character. Locations lack any deep story and feel like theyre just there to be cleared off the map. 

Stand out strength - It's a fun game. Whether I was riding an elephant into battle or bombing enemy convoys with a grenade launcher from a gyrocopter I was having fun with the game.

review: It's basically FarCry 3 rehashed and redone to be even more fun and ridiculous.  Which then makes it a fantastic game if you liked 3, but not so fantastic if you didn't care for 3.  Only about 15% completion so YMMV, but I would highly recommend this game if you enjoyed 3 but thought it just needed a few tweaks here and there.  Buyer beware, there are apparently some game-breaking glitches around, I personally haven't gotten to see any but they are there, but Ubi is supposedly working on them as they're reported.

review:
As a guy who has played a lot of Far Cry 3 I can say Far Cry 4 is really overrated/overhyped. It is very similiar to Far Cry 3 except some things:

+ They made the combat and gunplay even better
+ Better and more fun missions
+ Moral choices
+ More sidequests and randomly generated events
+ New fun arena mode

- Extremely bad protoganist that has no personality
- Bad story
- Bad endings that are very unsatisfying
- Laughably bad balancing and lots of retarded difficulty spikes
- Very boring multiplayer

I will also copy Gamespot's review of FC4 because I think it's very accurate:

70/100
"Like the terrain if depicts, Far Cry 4 travels both high and low, representing the good, the bad, and ugly of video games all at once. It's awesome and messy and dumb and fun and annoying and gross and beautiful. Take any given adjective in your vocabulary, and chances are, it will in some way describe Far Cry 4."

Far Cry 4 is a good game but it is not worth 60$. I would recommend buying it on sale or not buying it at all. It feels a lot more like an expansion for Far Cry 3 than a new game. The story and ending is really shitty, but the gameplay is great for the most part. I would probably rate 7 out of 10.

review: I loved Far Cry 3. Everything about it had me hooked like it was some kind of "e-crack". Far Cry 3 took the open world FPS genre to a new level. Far Cry 4 simply expands on that world. But don't be misled into thinking this is just Far Cry 3 with a new story line. While some aspects of this game are identical to its predecessor, this beast also has many new additions and features which allow it to stand out as its own game. Karma events, hostage rescue, re-playable outposts to continuously practice your assault skills on. The best thing that was added though, in my opinion, is how your choices affect the game down the road. Choose option A, this happens. Choose option B, that happens. Either option opens, or closes, new missions and storylines. At the end of the day I can tell you that if you enjoy the open world exploration FPS genre mix then chances are you're going to be very happy with this game.

review:
A standard Ubi affair that in usual Ubi way is marred by technical issies at launch. It is not a bad game, but its not outstanding in any way either. It feels unoptimized for PC. Like they just took the game for the consoles and added a bunch of bells and whistles to the ageing engine and pushed it out the door. I ran Far Cry 3 on a gtx 670 without problems. This one I have to use two to get the same kind of performance but the graphics are not that much better. In fact some of the new bells and whistles looks downright ugly and imbalanced, like the godrays system. 

The characters are not as memorable, except for the main villian and a couple of drugged up hippies. I was gifted this game and I would not encourage anyone to get it at full price. At least not before Ubisoft starts to treat PC gamers with more respect.

review: Still has alot of bugs. Several quests when complete to not update and require you to close the game. Towers when captured require you to close the game and redo at times. Arena is bugged at times, when your caught in a room and it loads the next rounds enemies your thrown outside and rendered "unseeable" so you can get to rank 15 relatively easy with this glitch if you dont close and reload the arena. I can actually go on for a ways about bugs, but I am sure it will all be fixed. Now , since you know the faults, here are the pro's. THE BEST GAME I HAVE PLAYED THE LAST COUPLE OF YEARS! If this does not get game of the year, it would greatly surprise me. Best SandBox game out their. To say this is like Skyrim with guns, would greatly under value this game. It smokes Skyrim. Graphics on Ultra High and I have dual 570s, and I still barely get 60 frames... AMAZING!!!!  This game has it all. MetaScore 9.8.

review:
Let me preface this review with the fact that I rum this on a higher end computer.

Now that I've covered that base, Far Cry 4 is  great (minus uplay, of course).

Good:
- The game is stunning and just so mesmerizing that I find myself caught up in the settings beauty and not actually playing the game
- Very similar to far cry 3 in many ways, which is mostly good because the game expands on many of the good points of its predecessor
-  Gyrocopter isn't incredibly op but suprisingly balanced
-Recurve Bow w/ reflex sight-so much fun- and other on lead free weapons grant double the skin when slaughter the magnificent and terrifying creatures of Kyrat. Which brings me to my next point...
- The magnificent and terrifying creatures of Kyrat. Getting attacked from all angles, honey badgers, HONEY F**KING BADGERS, eagles from the sky, and gods knows what else.
- Mortars in outpots make taking your sweet time on liberating an outpost more challenging which makes you a better player/bowman
-ELEPHANTS YOU CAN RIDE INTO BATTLE

Not so Good:
- The Karma system is a little weird times and is kind of annoying at times with the amount of karma events.
- The honey badgers don't care how many times you have shot them with a shotgun they do not want do die.
- skill tree is a little weird with the setup

Bad:
- Uplay startup/ Uplay in general
- generally easy decision on who to side with on choice missions (no spoilers here)
-Uplay

Downright offensive:
-Uplay

Overall 9/10

review: I love the far cry series and think that Ubisoft is a great developer.  I loved playing Far Cry 3 on the xbox 360 and I have far cry 2 on my PC.  However, Far Cry 4 has really disappointed me on the PC.  First I started having major lag issues.  I fixed this by downloading a driver for my Radeon Graphics card, which said "Driver for optimized gaming on (Some Title I can't remember) and Far Cry 4".  Given this was kinda Radeon's fault, but I also think that whatever the hell Ubisoft and Nvidia did to Far Cry 4 to make my graphics card shit itself for no reason other than whatever that driver fixed makes it partially their faults.  This fixed the Lag issue but than it started having shitty fps.  So I started to work on this problem and then when I tryed to launch Far Cry 4 it would not launch.  The uplay window would simply open up and say "Thankyou for playing Far Cry 4".  I haven't found a fix yet and I'm not feeling the delet and redownload  fiasco so I'm thinking I'll wait a few weeks to see if this shit gets patched up.  Truely disappointed, that being said the game looks so fun and I want to play it really badly.  I have 16gb of vram and an i7 core at 2.5 ghz.  I mean tell me if I'm under powered but according to recommended specs for this game I should be golden.

review:
What am I doing here?

I'll go past the glitchy black bars, the flickering paper-thin trees, and the inability to remap the controls I've experienced so far in this buggy game.

After 4 hours of play, I have to ask myself, my character "what am I doing here?," "why am I being shot at?"

You come to an island to get rid of your mom's ashes, only to be almost-killed on numerous occasions. Then, it tuns out your now-dead mom knew that would happen all along, but without a warning she planned your visit. The supposedly-insane and wild villan treats you to a nice meal and a place to rest your head, but you don't get a chance to enjoy it as a gang of gun-slinging dudes come in to "rescue" you. 

After that point you are thrown into the broken world of annoying mountains and obstacles. Fighting for a goal you couldn't care less. 

What am I doing in this place? Why am I helping these people? Why am I risking my life for all of this?

There's no motivation for my character to be in this place. None at all. I'm just throwing myself into battles because the game wants me to. At one point I found myself being shot at by "hunters," and I had absolutely no freakin' idea who they were or why they were trying to kill me.

All the basic elements of the genius Far Cry 3 are rehashed in this game: the towers, the outposts, the plants, and the animals. But there's no decent story, no motivation, no plot. You're just thrown into the place.

In Far Cry 3, right from the start, you were given no choice: you were forced to move on, to get stronger, to save those close to you because they were too big a part of who you are.

In Far Cry 4, you're meant to care about a dead woman you never knew, who supposedly knew you were going to meet danger but did not bother to warn you. You're meant to fight against a villan who loved your mom and who treated you nicely. It's just.... weak, dumb, and pointless.

I feel I can leave the world of Far Cry 4 at any second and nothing in my character's life would change; not for the worse at least, only for the better. Why should I care to scatter some random woman's (main character's mom) ashes in a warzone? Why should I care if some random guy (main characer's dad) was supposedly a badass at this place? Why does my characer constantly agree to risk his life to rescue a bunch of "hostages" simply because a random guy tells me to; while himself doing nothing for those hostages?

Just like Skyrim, Far Cry 4's positives are nothing by nostalgia whiffed off the previous iteration that ignore all the glaring bugs, plot holes, and lack of characterization.

I'm glad Far Cry 3  was great. It was amazing. It's the only justification I can give myself for spending $100 on the buggy, rushed, and barely-thought-through Far Cry 4.

All good things must come to an end, I guess. Far Cry 4 is the coffin of Far Cry 3.

--------

[b]June, 2015 EDIT:[/b]
After waiting for critical bug fixes and buying a new, 16:9 monitor to fix the black bars issues, I've actually played and completed this game.

I suppose 60 hours of entertainment (and more, since I'll likely play it again in the future) justify the $100 I paid for the full super-duper edition. But it's an incredibly lazy re-hash of Far Cry 3 and it shows and that's what annoys me. It could've been an amazing Top-All-Time game if UbiSoft spent another year on it.

I've came across many bugs and glitches that look like problems swept under the rug by the devs/quality assurance team. The unlocks are incredibly unbalanced: you get a ton of unlocks at one time, then nothing for a long period. You get the best guns almost at the start of the game, so there's no point in getting any of the other ones. And the best and most fun gun to take out the outposts with is locked until you've completed 23 out 24 outposts. Ridiculous.

The writing is abhorrent. It serves no other purpose than to interrupt your pillaging of outposts. I didn't hate the villan: he was just a dictator, subjugating the people I didn't care about. I suppose it's bad, but should I do something about it? I didn't like the protagonists: they're obnoxious, ugly, and incessantly cry for help. Most of the missions you're told to do something while they all sit somewhere comfy. You're supposed to care for Kyrat because it's your birthplace, but you're constantly being told that you left when you were very young and you don't remember any of it. Should I care about a piece of land that was proximate to my mother's womb when I was born? Please!

The choices you make with the two supposed leaders of the Golden Path are non-choices. At one point I had to decide whether to side with Amita and keep the drug fields to make money to rebuild Kyrat or to side with Sabal and burn the field down because it's "not who we are." But that's a non-choice! I'm not given any alternative on how to rebuild Kyrat if we destroy the drugs. Amita says without the drugs we'll live in poverty and Sabal makes no counterargument! 

The details of the choices are moot, however, because they have absolutely no impact at the end.

Speaking of the end, what a load of manure it is! You can definitely find the various endings on YouTube, but the one I ended up with didn't even resolve the initial conflict. The very reason why my character decided to stay in Kyrat instead of legging it! I killed the bad gun with a boring shot to the head from a pistol during a cutscene and instantly it faded and I was shown "FIN." What about tea-bagging the guy? Good grief!

Lazy. Obnoxious. Pallid. An overpriced reskin of Far Cry 3, to be enjoyable by people who loved Far Cry 3.

--------

[b]March, 2016 EDIT:[/b]

After more than a year of having this game, I recently started another playthrough, and I'm actually changing my Not Recommended rating to Recommended. The most annoying bugs have been patched. The price of the game went down as well. Yes, it's still a cash grab with stupid story, but there are enjoyable elements of traipsing through grassy slopes in sunny weather, shooting goats, and occasional terrorists, in the head.

I suppose 60 hours of entertainment (and more, since I'll likely play it again in the future) justify the $100 I paid for the full super-duper edition. But it's an incredibly lazy re-hash of Far Cry 3 and it shows and that's what annoys me. It could've been an amazing Top-All-Time game if UbiSoft spent another year on it.

I've came across many bugs and glitches that look like problems swept under the rug by the devs/quality assurance team. The unlocks are incredibly unbalanced: you get a ton of unlocks at one time, then nothing for a long period. You get the best guns almost at the start of the game, so there's no point in getting any of the other ones. And the best and most fun gun to take out the outposts with is locked until you've completed 23 out 24 outposts. Ridiculous.

The writing is abhorrent. It serves no other purpose than to interrupt your pillaging of outposts. I didn't hate the villan: he was just a dictator, subjugating the people I didn't care about. I suppose it's bad, but should I do something about it? I didn't like the protagonists: they're obnoxious, ugly, and incessantly cry for help. Most of the missions you're told to do something while they all sit somewhere comfy. You're supposed to care for Kyrat because it's your birthplace, but you're constantly being told that you left when you were very young and you don't remember any of it. Should I care about a piece of land that was proximate to my mother's womb when I was born? Please!

The choices you make with the two supposed leaders of the Golden Path are non-choices. At one point I had to decide whether to side with Amita and keep the drug fields to make money to rebuild Kyrat or to side with Sabal and burn the field down because it's "not who we are." But that's a non-choice! I'm not given any alternative on how to rebuild Kyrat if we destroy the drugs. Amita says without the drugs we'll live in poverty and Sabal makes no counterargument! 

The details of the choices are moot, however, because they have absolutely no impact at the end.

Speaking of the end, what a load of manure it is! You can definitely find the various endings on YouTube, but the one I ended up with didn't even resolve the initial conflict. The very reason why my character decided to stay in Kyrat instead of legging it! I killed the bad gun with a boring shot to the head from a pistol during a cutscene and instantly it faded and I was shown "FIN." What about tea-bagging the guy? Good grief!

Lazy. Obnoxious. Pallid. An overpriced reskin of Far Cry 3, to be enjoyable by people who loved Far Cry 3.

--------

[b]March, 2016 EDIT:[/b]

After more than a year of having this game, I recently started another playthrough, and I'm actually changing my Not Recommended rating to Recommended. The most annoying bugs have been patched. The price of the game went down as well. Yes, it's still a cash grab with stupid story, but there are enjoyable elements of traipsing through grassy slopes in sunny weather, shooting goats, and occasional terrorists, in the head.", "timestamp_created": 1417143371, "timestamp_updated": 1457061825, "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "weighted_vote_score": 0.5, "comment_count": 4, "steam_purchase": true, "received_for_free": false, "written_during_early_access": false, "primarily_steam_deck": false}

review:
HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.
It had an issue when released that made the game to crash when some USB controller was plugged. Now, fixed with patch 1.4.0.
Graphics are perfect. Characters movements are absolutely real, as well as face motion but, not only in main characters or just people, animals move as the real thing. Incredible!.

The world map is huge, variate and interesting enough.
Everything is alive and, random. You can be trying to get a post and then, several wild animals attack you; if you shoot them, you discover your position. ha ha ha. You should see how an eagle gets a goat or any other animal, how rinos charge against your car, etc. Awesome!.

Respect of FC3, a few more weapons, vehicles and, everything together was added.

There are some psicodelic missions and, some interesting new side quests or missions.
Missions on the snow and ice are specially good and, the escape from the prision is apotheosic (I've even seen the Yeti !!!).

The game delivers lots of playing hours and, scenarios are so good that it's funny to explore the whole map. High re-playability and, the possibility to play it in cooperative mode (campaign).
It has also some Multiplayer online game modes, which I didn't test so, I have no opinion, yet.

In the bad side, I could only say that to understand how to continue the main plot(s) takes a while and that, there are so many key assignments. IMHO, the interface could be reduced a lot to fewer keys, to make it easier to control your character  / vehicles / weapons.

Ok. Ubisoft failed delivering a game that hung if you had any USB device plugged (fixed with patch 1.4.0), what made angry to most of players, which were expecting the release date to death. This included myself, as well.
But, the amount of effort behind this game is colossal. Another great work from Ubisoft Montreal, a joy of game programming.
It worths the money.

review:
Short Review

Gameplay: 8/10 (better than most)
Graphics: 10/10 (stunning)
Mechanics: 7/10 (best played with a controller... keyboarding a selection wheel is a bit awkward)
Music: 4/10 (annoying as hell unless you have a red dot on your forehead)
Co-Op: 7/10 (needs more but works pretty well with what it has currently)
Attacking killer eagles: -5/10  (fuq those eagles)

Long Review

So no surprise, FC4 is exactly like FC3... which is not at all a bad thing.  First of all, the game is gourgeous... long gone seem to be the days when beautiful cutscenes gave way to dismal graphics during the actual gameplay.  This game, to say the very least, is visually stunning. The new environment seems to work well (although you do have to suspend reality a few times-- crocodiles at high altitudes in the Himmalayns?)  Gamers with moderate PCs will be pleasantly surprised by medium graphics settings but of course, to truly take it all in, the highest settings are where it's at.

Gameplay is good, although its a bit buggy-- especially with the online co-op.  There seems to be a problem with syncing some of the casual encounters that the game offers such as taking out roving patrols and courriers between you and your co-op companion at times making these missions difficult, if not impossible to complete.  There are also issues with loading (especially after fast-traveling or completing a quest) in the SP mode where the game fails to load properly and you get a blank screen with sound.  Although this has happened a few times, it doesn't occur all that often and isn't anything that should keep you from buying the game.

So far, the biggest dissapointment of the game is the co-op mode which has fairly limited accessibility in terms of what you and your partner can actually do and the progress that can be saved.  Co-op mode only allows the joining party to save money, weapons, skins, etc... no quest progress is saved.  This means that aside from collecting new weapons and such, the joining partner will not really get all that much accomplished within their own campaign leading to a lot of play overs.  Additionally, there are many things available in SP that are no available in co-op.  The hosting party will not be able to complete any campaign missions while in co-op mode, and thus will be unable to advance the geography while in a co-op match.  This would lead one to conclude that co-op should be undertaken after one has already completed a good portion of the campaign and has unlocked many of the locales and side missions that can be undertaken together.  This is a little dissapointing compared with games like Borderlands which allow both parties to advance simultaneously.  Not sure why they didn't go in that direction but nonetheless, I'm happy to have the co-op in any form.

The biggest complaint I have about the game so far is the inability to replay things in co-op mode that would allow for a longer, more satisfying experience.  My co-op companion and I are obsessed with stealthing everything and were dissapointed that we were unable to replay fortress and outpost captures within the co-op mode.  That is something that I certainly feel needs changing.

Other than that, FC4 is an extremely solid game that rewards players for almost everything that you can do within it.   Hopefully in the coming months and expansions they expand the co-op mode a little and this game will get a lot closer to a perfect score.  For now, I plant this game at a solid 8.5/10.  Absolutely worth the money.

review:
After seeing way too many negative reviews for this game I figured I needed to write my own. Just so it is clear I am writing this review after playing 19 hours and beating the campaign.

    Gameplay
    The basic gameplay is very similar to Far Cry 3. You have campaign missions, side missions, liberate towers, and of course attack outposts. The biggest gameplay differences are throughout the main campaign you have two leaders arguing and you always need to be the decider. Second gameplay difference is now there are fortresses, which are a lot more fun too attack since they pose a little more difficulty. Third, the map being based in the hills has a lot more opportunities to make use of the grappling hook and the wing-suits. Finally the side missions are a lot more common and varied to keep it interesting even after you have finished the main campaign. I know I still have a ton of the map to explore. Overall the gameplay was familiar and I really enjoyed it but it didn't feel like an exact replica of Far Cry 3, they really improved the base model of gameplay

    Graphics
    I have a custom built hi-end PC and I was able to take full advantage of the high graphics quality. Everything from the characters to the terrain to the animals all looks so amazing and only a few games able to compare with that level. I know that for people with lower end computers it may not be as important, but for someone who can run it, the graphics are amazing. I understand many (too many) players have had issues with the game from black screens to frame stuttering, I have not had these issues since the launch day but I hope Ubisoft fixes them all for everyone's sake.

    Story
    While I was very skeptical of the story having to follow the amazing story brought to us in Far Cry 3. That being said the story is very well written. It has plenty of hooks and switches to keep you guessing from the start. One thing I will mention that there are several opportunities to shoot a person before they tell you their part of the story, I just wish that was a little more obvious so nobody misses any.

    Sounds
    As usual the background music for the whole story was amazing as well as all the sound effects. Everything fit very well together and made the game one step closer to perfection.

    My Closing Opinion
    I loved the game. I do feel that the story was unable to match Far Cry 3 but was still amazing. I love the vehicles and coop was a nice addition. I know I will still be playing this game every second of my free time for probably another month or two. I know I still have plenty of submissions and collectibles lying around to keep me entertained for a while.

Thank you @Orbitaldrop for the vertical gameplay and side missions addition

Edit 2020:
Stil one of the best FarCry games.

review: Is this worth $60? IMO I say yes. There is lots to do and you can choose different ways to branch out the story. The graphics are absolutely top notch so if you are considering getting this from steam make sure you have a decent computer so that you can enjoy the visuals. The only thing I don't like about the game is that the NPC enemies all have ridiculous aim-bot and when you take cover if there is one pixel of you showing you will still get hit even if the attacker is hip firing from 500 meters away. Oh and sipers never, ever, ever, miss. But overall this game is in a league of it's own and even though I beat the campaign I'm not even half way done with completing the game!

review:
Honestly one of the worst games I have played in a while. I wish there was a numbering scale so I could rate it a 1. To say that it is recommended or not is an understatement. While I understand making a game "hard" is one thing, to completely change the dynamics halfway through is another. I dont understand, did they not play the game through after they finished coding it? The game doesn't follow. A throwing knife most of the way through the game will kill, unless you are playing certain levels, in which case it will just irritate the baddies. The storyline doesn't make a whole lot of sense, and the game is optimised mostly for Co-op. It utilizes the same graphics engine, same basic design principle, even the same sounds!! To say the least I am dissappointed. Ubisoft is getting soft. All of the other Far Cry games pushed the envelope. They even used a new graphics engine each time. The only thing new is the area you're playing in. Same idea, same guns, same stupid AI, just a different "area". Want to unlock a new portion of the map? Better climb a radio tower!! UBISOFT is not the same developer as they used to be. They, and this game are a bitter dissapointment.

I have purchased all of the Far Cry games and this is the worst by far; its also the last I will ever purchase. Basically, the main difference is you can ride an elephant. And basically,  I paid $60 to ride one. Don't fall for it. This game isn't worth the money. Wait until is goes on sale for $10 and maybe buy it then.

review: Considering this is a Ubisoft game I'm kindof suprised they called it Farcry 4. While the game is good, it is not what I would consider to be a whole number greater than Farcry 3. This game is more like Assasin's Creed Brotherhood. A title on its own, but not a number in the series. Like Fallout: New Vegas, this game is good in its own right, but lacked the emotional experiences in the previous game. Still a good game and a good buy.

review:
The storyline is much worst then the one from the 3rd. 
In Far Cry 3 you feel the character progression as he turns from a rich brat afraid of real problems, to a true "tattau" wearing warrior. In this one, your a guy with a urn of your mothers ashes, that somehow you can carry them with you at all times in your pants (that's where he takes it from when he wants to look at them), and suddently you are in a forein place and you don't really seem to mind killing all these people, and you also suddently know how to use all types of weapons.

I'm 2 missions close to finishing the main quest, and still don't see any repercussions for the choices I made. I feel like it's going to be like Mass Effect 3 all over again - so much tough decisions for a meaningless ending. I'm taking this time to finish every bit of the game, but at this point it's just a repetition. I have captured all the enemy bases (except 1 fortress), done all the major side quests, all the radio towers, all the fashion week quests and loads of spinny totem things and propaganda - still I'm at 50% of the game. If 100% means stepping in every square meter of the map, picking all treasure chests and all the stuff, either I'm going to leave the game at 60% or something or I'm going to be bored to death.

All and all, this past 26.2 hours of gaming have been fun - some quests are repetitive (like the ones from the priest, always catching diamonds the same exact way), but still a positive experience. The only thing I'm "mad" about is that I feel as they have been lazy, so much potential in this game and they kind of rushed through it and just looped a bunch of things! But I still recommend this game. 

If you do buy this - you will have at least 25h of fun. Explore stuff, enjoy small things like watching an entire army be crumbled by an array of random events like rhino attacks, or troll a flamethrower enemy that cant never reach you from your helicopter but wont stop trying until he inevitably kills himself by accident.

review: While out hunting for crafting materials I spotted an eagle close to were I was and decided to shoot it with my sniper rifle (becuase they are probably one of the most annoying animals in the game).  As I tracked the eagle through my sight it swooped down and grabbed a nearby wild boar and soared off with it's prey.   I took the shot  killing the eagle in one hit which led to the boar falling down the side of a mountain to the floor below 10/10

review:
It's a lot like Far Cry 3; just with more content. That's about all there is to say about it. Too bad the game isn't optimized for AMD Video Cards well (HD7850 and some stuttering even on medium graphics level).

It's okay.

review:
I absolutely loved Far Cry 3. I beat the singleplayer, the coop campaign with 3 buddies, and hit max level in multiplayer. You can see my Far Cry 3 pvp videos on youtube, including "Rambo Mode", named by PCGamesN as one of the top 10 entertaining FC3 videos. Based on my love for Far Cry 3 I went ahead, on blind faith, and preordered the deluxe edition of this game.

With that said, what a massive disappointment this game is. There isn't any one single aspect that breaks it for me. Instead, I would call it death by a thousand cuts.

First off I want to address the absolutely undebatable. Something that has nothing to do with personal taste. This game is BUGGY AS ALL HELL. Several times I've randomly slid backwards up hills as if an invisible force was dragging me backward. I've died from 5 foot drops, and in the next moment fell 30 feet and didn't take a single point of damage. Birds constantly land in midair. I've seen up to 4 birds all perched in the sky, and it's not due to draw distance -- this happens even a few meters away on ultra detail. If you skin an animal and your inventory is full, that animal is forever broken and cannot be skinned, even if you drop items to free up space. To add insult, they still glow white as if lootable. Small bugs like this are absolutely pervasive, and affect nearly every mechanic in the game.

Looking past the bugs, this game is also riddled with poor design decisions. Perhaps the most outrageous and baffling is that there is a constant tiny radius around you during every single mission where if you walk 10 feet out of it, you lose. I thought this was an open world game? An early game example is when you have to pick between two quest givers and there is a propaganda poster less than 50 feet away from them. But you can't pick it up. If you do, you'll fail the mission for being out of bounds, and you'll have to watch the entire mission intro cutscene again which is several minutes long. You might say "well, damn! That's not a big deal! I'll just turn around if the message pops up!" Good luck. All the most fun ways to travel (wingsuit, gyrocopter, handglider, etc) move so fast that you'll get game over'd a split second after you see the message. This game is an open world game that arbitrarily decides it doesn't want to be open world anymore. It wasn't such an issue in Far Cry 3 because a) it was far more rare, b) the boundaries were far less confined, and c) there were clear out-of-bounds lines shown on the map when this type of rule applied. Not here.

In coop, we experienced falling through the world. Respawning and instantly dying as if falling from a great height. Terrible syncing issues, such as seeing whole groups of enemies and vehicles that my coop partner did not. This was not a consistent issue, but it's something we never experienced in all of our hours playing Far Cry 3. The most ridiculous death I had was getting teleported to my buddy because he had wingsuited off a cliff. It teleported me close to him in mid-air, in my own wing suit, headed straight toward a cliff wall and I promptly died.

The PVP is so bad now I'm not even going to waste words on it.

A lot of people complained about Far Cry 3's story, but this story is just flat and lifeless. Pagan Min seems entertaining enough, but your character's motivation -- what we're supposed to relate to -- is meaningless. You're here to spread your mother's ashes -- so logically you might as well stay and instantly transform into a super soldier. Criticise Far Cry 3's Jason Brody all you want, but at least he had an easily relatable motivation -- revenge, and a modicum of development. He changed, however unlikely, from a terrified kid into a guerilla leader. In this, your character literally goes from being a bored sounding tourist with no desire to be involved in the war, to hanging up on the rebel leader offering you backup and telling her you are going to destroy the very first enemy outpost in the game by yourself. Why? "Because I can handle this." And your character still sounds incredibly bored about it all. I can't stress how bored your character sounds at every moment of the game.

I am scratching my head trying to understand how they could take a solid game like Far Cry 3 and break so many aspects of it. The grappling is cool. Some of the new wildlife is cool. The graphics are gorgeous. But everything else? I'm just not happy with my purchase at all. I should have loved this game, but the only emotions I felt while playing coop were boredom and anger, punctuated by an incredibly rare moment of "wow, that was cool". Those rare moments were not worth $60, let alone $90.

review:
It's a worthy sequel to Far Cry 3, but not quite as good. The creative story definitely has it's moments, and contains a good amount of choices you will have to make. The overall gameplay is extremely similar to 3, liberate outposts, radio towers, and spread the uprising. If you liked 3, you will most likely enjoy 4.
8/10

review:
If you enjoyed Far Cry 3 then you will enjoy 4. I have the Nvidia GeForce GTX 780 Ti video card and did not experience any of the technical problems some users reported on release day. The game plays just like 3, just think of it as new content. Which is not a bad thing to me. Some people complained its the same game mechanics as the previous game. So what? If it isn't broke why fix it? Graphics are good, no complaint there. Ive noticed a few minor glitches in the game but that's when Ive been playing a solid 8+ hours and a simple exit and restart fixed it.

For my pet-peeves... You can not skip/escape any of the cut scenes. Some which are unnecessary long and boring. And if they are part of a mission you have to restart because you died or something it sucks all over again. Ive been annoyed by magically spawning animals that seem to eat me when im in battle with a NPC. A few times animals ive been hunting have despawned while in view of my character. Have also lost a few vehicles that have despawned when i walked 50 meters away (or is the game using feet?) while other times i can go a long ways and come back and its still there. Not sure what is the game logic that triggers a despawn.

Other then that, i really enjoy the game, i don't regret buying it. I have 50 hours in and just reached the middle mark of the game. Well worth it, Id have to say its the best game ive played this year. And yes i also played COD:AW which annoyed me ALOT more and is very linear / scripted.
Not until many bugs are fixed.

review:
If you liked FC3 you should love this. Pretty much the same feel as FC3 with some improvements and additions. Driving is greatly improved and you can shoot while driving. Grappeling was added and leads to some awesome cliff-hanging parkor kind of stuff. They also added random events into the mix; hijack supply trucks, blow up convoys, and save the locals from wildlife to name a few.

I was initially disappointed to see that the 4 person co-op was gone. I am very pleased with what we got. What we now have is being able to bring one friend into your single player game and it seems to work really well. Now you have an open world, random events, and a friend? Just try it..

I've barely dipped my toe into the PVP waters but what I've seen here looks really interesting. 5v5 various maps with differing objectives, nothing really new here. What is interesting is the different factions. You have the Golden Path that uses your typical gun and explosive type weapons and the Rakshasa who are more stealthy and use bows and animals. Wouldn't seem like a fair fight but they pull it off. I played an Outpost map and you play a round, flip factions, and play another round. 

All in all I'm really enjoying the game and if you are a fan of FC3 or the whole FC franchise you'll probably enjoy it as well.

review:
People who say that this game is extremely similar to Far Cry 3 in both concept and design, are right. However, this doesn't necessarily make it a bad game, and with all of its improvements that it has done to it, its similarities actually make it a way better game than Far Cry 3 ever was. I loved Far Cry 3, don't get me wrong, but it had its crappy moments, like bad guys all miraculously disappearing when you take out an outpost, or having weapon types. However, Far Cry 4 took all of this, and expanded on it, like adding in karma events, similar to random events from GTA V, which adds a little randomness to the overall gameplay, a much needed improvement from the dull post-campaign world of Far Cry 3. Weapons like the recurve bow, also feel like they have been significantly buffed, but not in a cheap way, making it almost like a medium-range sniper rifle. The new hunter enemy is also a cool addition, because unlike previous enemy types, he isn't a bullet cushion that shoots a cloud of bullets or fire at you, he actually hides from you, and even ambushes you in a style that hasn't been seen before in Far Cry. In a game where it feels like the enemies are borderline mentally disabled, it feels good to have an actual AI capable of coordinating a stealth attack consisting of several bow-wielding foes, as well as "charmed" animals that will fight for the hunters. Bad things for the game are few, but I personally felt the story wasn't as engaging as the story in Far Cry 3 was, but that's my opinion. Also, I experienced a glitch midway through the game that forced me to restart my entire game, which involved a blackscreen at a crucial point in the story, which I exited, and resulted in my being stuck in the overworld with no weapons forever, prompting me to restart. 

 In summary, is Far Cry 4 a clone of Far Cry 3 like everyone says? For the most part, yes, but the vast improvements made on it from Far Cry 3 make it pretty much an evolved version of said game, and I have absolutely no problem with that. Far Cry 4 is an awesome experience using the best that the Far Cry team could provide, and it shows. Although the campaign was lacking from the previous game, the gameplay and new implemented elements make up for this. I definitley recommend this game, especially since it looks like all of the updates to clear out game-wrecking glitches are finally out there.

P.S. I hope you don't have a problem with killing animals to get upgraded equipment.
